Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Web-Based Versus In-Person Followup After Total Joint Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: 256 patients who were at least 12 months post-primary total hip or knee arthroplasty were randomised

Participants.evidence: 256 patients who were at least 12 months post-primary total hip or knee arthroplasty were randomised to either a web-based followup or an in-person clinic visit. The study was conducted at a single orthopedic center.

Intervention.evidence: randomised to either a web-based followup or an in-person clinic visit

Objective.evidence: This study investigates patient satisfaction with web-based followup compared to traditional in-person followup after total joint arthroplasty

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was patient satisfaction, assessed at the time of followup and one year later for the web-based group.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applicable due to the nature of the interventions.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 256 patients who were at least 12 months post-primary total hip or knee arthroplasty were randomised

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 229 patients completed the study (111 in the usual-care group, 118 in the web-based group).

Result_Outcome.evidence: Satisfaction was higher in the usual-care group, with 82.0% reporting being extremely or very satisfied, compared to 75.6% in the web-based group (p < 0.01; OR = 3.95; 95% CI, 1.79–8.76).
